column1: Samannud (Arabic: سمنود‎ Samannūd) is a city (markaz) located in Gharbia Governorate
column2: Egypt. Known in classical antiquity as Sebennytos (Greek: Σεβέννυτος)
column3: Samannud is a historic city that has been inhabited since the Ancient Egyptian period. As of 2019
column4: the population of the markaz of Samannud was estimated to be 410

column1: The name Samannud ultimately derives from the Ancient Egyptian name ṯb-(n)-nṯr
column2: meaning "city of the sacred calf". The name was probably pronounced */ˌcabˈnaːcar/ in Old Egyptian and */ˌcəbˈnuːtə/ or */ˌcəbənˈnuːtə/ in Late Egyptian.

column1: Samannud (Sebennytos) was an ancient city of Lower Egypt
column2: located on the now-silted up Sebennytic branch of the Nile in the Delta. Sebennytos was the capital of Lower Egypt's twelfth nome—the Sebennyte nome (district). Sebennytos was also the seat of the Thirtieth Dynasty of Egypt (380–343 BCE).Sebennytos is perhaps best known as the hometown of Manetho
column3: a historian and chronicler from the Ptolemaic era
column4: c. 3rd century BC. Sebennytos was also the hometown of Nectanebo II; he was its last ruler.A temple dedicated to the local god Anhur
column6: and his lioness goddess mate Mehit
column7: once existed at this location but is now reduced to ruins. A fragment from the location where kings would have made offerings to Anhur and his wife
column8: is on display at the Walters Art Museum.

column1: Samannud violently resisted the Muslim conquest of Egypt in 639
column2: and remained rebellious for some time thereafter; the city revolted four times in the first half of the eighth century. Three Coptic Patriarchs came from Samannud: John III
column4: and John V. The 12th-century Coptic philologist Yuhanna al-Samannudi also came from Samannud

column6: which was sent to Cairo.The 1885 Census of Egypt recorded Samannud as a city in its own district in Gharbia Governorate; at that time

column2: Sebennytos was part of the route of the Holy Family during the flight into Egypt narrated in the Gospel of Matthew (2:13–23).
